text: hello and welcome to
community chats i'm your host ali hammer
and today on the show we have rob taylor
a solution architect here at aws
talking all things amazon narratives
so rob what is a narrative why do we
write them
can you tell us about it sure so a
narrative is basically
you know just if you want to implement
something new at aws you want to change
a process
uh you generally have to write a
narrative that explains why
something needs to change and uh the
most important feature of it is that
it's actually data-driven
so i personally written a narrative
myself it's very daunting you sit in a
room there's complete silence
everybody gets handed your narrative and
and they read through it and then
there's an open discussion after that
why do we have this process uh because
it really makes people actually
think about what's going on in the
narrative it really makes you sit down
and is there an alternative is the data
that's being presented here
actually a call to do what the person is
saying
and oftentimes i've done a narrative
before as well
and sometimes the data that you
presented it's really important data
and the actual action is something that
comes out of that
meeting sitting down and having people
discuss what's been presented and
sometimes it's just 180 degrees in the
opposite direction of what you were
thinking yeah it's true i mean it does
force you to look
really critically at what you're
thinking about and before you present it
um rob how long did it take you to write
your narrative personally it took me a
few days so is it a week
a month like how long should it take so
i've had narratives that took me
yeah a week to write and i've had
narratives that i wrote in three hours
and i really i think a lot of times it
does depend on
you know sometimes people write these
narratives and they're not necessarily
being driven
by data they're being driven by i have
an idea and i'm going to shoot in the
data until it fits and i think a lot of
those times
that's when you start seeing people
write these month-long narratives but
when something's really clear after
you've seen a piece of data and you're
like wow that's
really strange i wonder how we can fix
that or wonder how we can improve on
that
um sometimes the narrative kind of
writes itself yeah that's true
um i guess like what does a person who's
writing a narrative hope to achieve
you've got everyone in the room they're
sitting down they're reading it
what's the outcome that they want to
achieve at the end a change in process
activates almost always what what you're
looking for
and sometimes that change in process is
extreme like in
an aws sense maybe someone has developed
an idea for a new service
and sometimes it's really minor but it
can have some pretty severe customer
impacts
thank you so much rob i really
appreciate your insights and we'll see
you next time
bye
